channel.title: A-Frame
channel.description: A web framework for building virtual reality experiences. Make WebVR with HTML and Entity-Component. Works on Vive, Rift, desktop, mobile platforms.

item.title: A-Frame selected for the 2024 Github accelerator
item.description: A-Frame is honored to participate with other 10 amazing projects in the 2024 cohort of the
item.content:encoded: A-Frame is honored to participate with other 10 amazing projects in the 2024 cohort of the Github accelerator. A-Frame has been making 3D content creation fun and accesible since 2015. Generative AI will open new and exciting avenues to onboard anyone regardless of technical expertise. Next decade going be the most exciting ever for the 3D Web.

item.title: A-Frame 1.6.0 - Memory management and performance improvements
item.description: A-Frame 1.6.0 is out! Tons of bug fixes. Memory management and performance improvements. API to control tick / tock
item.content:encoded:
A-Frame 1.6.0 is out! Tons of bug fixes. Memory management and performance improvements. API to control tick / tock execution order.

Find all details on the release notes and changelog

item.title: A-Frame 1.4.0 - Custom elements V1, Oculus Quest Pro support, tons of fixes and improvements
item.description:
A-Frame 1.4.0 is out! House keeping release. Tons of bug fixes and suppport for new devices.

More than 28 A-Frame
item.content:encoded:
A-Frame 1.4.0 is out! House keeping release. Tons of bug fixes and suppport for new devices.

More than 28 A-Framers helped to get 1.4.0 out of the door including friends from Oculus, Microsoft and Samsung.

Find all details on the release notes and changelog and see all friends that are helping to make all this happen.

Consider supporting A-Frame development by buying a gorgeous t-shirt or sponsoring on github

Happy immersive 2023!

item.title: A-Frame 1.1.0 - AR, Quest 2 Support, hand tracking, compositor layers, immersive navigation
item.description: A-Frame 1.1.0 is out! Core functionality is more polished and robust than ever. Full support for WebXR AR module and initial and experimental integration for upcoming and exciting WebXR APIs like immersive navigation, hand tracking, compositor layers or hit tests
item.content:encoded:
A-Frame 1.1.0 is out! Core functionality is more polished and robust than ever. Full support for WebXR AR module and initial and experimental integration for upcoming and exciting WebXR APIs like immersive navigation, hand tracking, compositor layers or hit tests

This week also marks A-Frame‚Äôs fith birthday. Five years ago, on December, 2015, we released the first version of A-Frame to make it easier for anyone to build VR experiences. What started as a little personal project it‚Äôs today a community of hundreds of thousands of developers worldwide.

More than 40 A-Framers helped to get 1.1.0 across the finish line. 20 of those made their first contribution. We appreciate help from everybody and newcomers are always especially celebrated. A-Frame is only as strong as its community.

We also thank Google and Oculus WebXR teams. They made an outstanding effort in a tough year. They kept the Immersive Web standard moving forward with new APIs while delivering new implementations in Chrome and the Oculus browsers.

Read the release notes and changelog to check all the new features and celebrate everyone that made it happen.

Consider supporting A-Frame development by buying a gorgeous t-shirt

Happy immersive Christmas! üéÑ

item.title: Image Tracking and Location-Based AR with A-Frame and AR.js 3
item.description:
We‚Äôre happy to announce AR.js 3 and A-Frame integration featuring new image and location based tracking.

For detailed API reference and source code check the official documentation and the Github repository
item.content:encoded:
We‚Äôre happy to announce AR.js 3 and A-Frame integration featuring new image and location based tracking.

For detailed API reference and source code check the official documentation and the Github repository

Getting Started with Image Tracking

The new AR.js tracking can take any arbitrary image or drawing (not only markers) to position and display your 3D content.

You just need a high resolution image with a good amount of detail. The more complexity in the image the better the tracking. Learn how to choose images for best results in this article by Daniel Fernandes.

For this tutorial we will use the following image:

Creating Image Descriptors

Next step is to create image descriptors: a set of files that describe your image and are needed by the tracking algorithm. We will use the NFT Marked creator available via Web (also available locally as a node.js script if you prefer). Upload your image and click ‚Äúgenerate‚Äù to create the descriptors. Once the image is processed three files will automatically download. Copy the following snippet of code on a new HTML file and host it on a server. Also a Codepen with all the necessary code is available below for convenience.

Point <path-to-your-image-descriptors> to the path containing the Image Descriptors you generated and downloaded before. Those files will have a common name. Remove the file extension (e.g. with ‚Äúdinosaur.fset‚Äù, ‚Äúdinosaur.iset‚Äù and so on, the path you have to add should end with ‚Äúdinosaur‚Äù).

Serve the example from a local or remote server: Github Pages and Glitch are free and convenient options. Navigate to the URL on your device and you should see a T-Rex model after the loading screen disappears.

Visit this Codepen if you want to see right away how it looks without hosting your own.

You can replace the model above with any other assets: 2D videos, images, audio files. Any A-Frame a-entity is a valid child of the a-nft anchor.

Location-Based AR

Location-based tracking uses real-world coordinates to place AR content in context. Users can move freely (outdoors for better precision) and content associated with their location will be scaled and placed accordingly (e.g: content will render bigger / smaller based on distance to the user). With AR.js and A-Frame is now very easy to build experiences like cities and museum tours, restaurant guides, treasure hunts, biology or history learning games or place virtual art on any real world location.

The following example shows how to place text on a fixed position in the real world. The text will remain in place as you move around. The content is anchored to your current location. Make sure that GPS tracking is enabled on your device before you try.

Some notes:

  • Replace <add-your-latitude> and <add-your-longitude> with your GPS coordinates. There are several online services that lets you retrieve those data for free like latlong
  • Change the scale property according to the distance of the place you specified with the coordinates: if you are not seeing the text, try to scale it up or choose a place much near
  • We used the custom look-at A-Frame component, that makes the content always look towards the user camera. This is fundamental, in particular for 2D content as text.

Run the example on your device with GPS data on and you should be able to see the text fixed in place. Its position should honor the real-world positioning according to the GPS coordinates you added.

Unleash your creativity and replace the text with any content you like, thanks to A-Frame you can quickly display 3D models, videos, images: Any a-entity will be tracked as expected..

You can find additional support on the resources linked below and also on the official Gitter channel.

Have fun and please share the AR experiences you built with AR.js and A-Frame. We will love to check them out!

Nicolo Carpignoli and Diego Marcos.

Additional Resources

  • AR.js Repository
  • AR.js Documentation
  • Location-based Tutorials with AR.js

item.title: Experiment with AR and A-Frame
item.description:
Google Chrome and Oculus Browser are now shipping WebXR enabled by default for VR headsets. The Web magic doesn‚Äôt stop there. AR is also coming to the standard and you can experiment today on Android ARCore compatible devices and Chrome 79 or newer.

Enable the experimental WebXR AR module in chrome://flags and make sure your page is served over HTTPS. A-Frame 1.0.3 or newer automatically detects AR and shows the new Enter AR button:
item.content:encoded:
Google Chrome and Oculus Browser are now shipping WebXR enabled by default for VR headsets. The Web magic doesn‚Äôt stop there. AR is also coming to the standard and you can experiment today on Android ARCore compatible devices and Chrome 79 or newer.

Enable the experimental WebXR AR module in chrome://flags and make sure your page is served over HTTPS. A-Frame 1.0.3 or newer automatically detects AR and shows the new Enter AR button:

Build a scene in the same way than you do for VR. Just make sure that the background doesn‚Äôt block the camera view üôÇ

Try now on your ARCore phone and check out the source code

What about interactions?

When entering immersive mode, regular user DOM Events are disabled. There are two ongoing efforts to enable interactivity in AR experiences:

Hit Test

Developers will be able to cast rays into the real world and retrieve a list of intersection points against the real world understanding. A ray might be triggered by user input like touches or mouse clicks to for instance, place or move virtual objects in the real world.

DOM Overlay layer

When entering AR or VR mode, only WebGL content and the real world or camera image are rendered on screen. DOM layers will allow overlaying HTML elements to present for instance 2D UIs, instructions or contextual information associated to virtual or real world objects.

Join our discord channel. The community will love to see what you make.

If you‚Äôd like to continue to support us, please subscribe to the A-Frame newsletter where we‚Äôll not only provide updates and showcase community projects, but requests for testing and user feedback support every now and then to keep us going in this grassroots project.

item.title: A-Frame v1.0.0 - WebXR Support, AR Mode
item.description:
Today marks A-Frame‚Äôs fourth birthday. Four years ago, on December 16th, 2015, we released the first version of A-Frame to make it easier to build VR experiences and make the Web keep pace with the VR industry.

With the help of a community of hundreds of thousands of developers over the years, we‚Äôre releasing A-Frame v1.0.0 to support the coming out of the WebXR spec which has been under discussion for the past several years. The upgrade to A-Frame v1 and beyond will become necessary on more and more browsers as they deprecate WebVR and only support the WebXR specification.

To clear confusion, WebXR refers to both AR and VR support on the Web. To that end, we‚Äôve included an AR mode out of the box in A-Frame for browsers that support ARCore and ARKit. In production, make sure to use HTTPS for VR and AR support.

We‚Äôd like to thank in part Google for providing a bit of funding to us at Supermedium to help develop and maintain WebXR support for A-Frame. And to thank people within Google, Oculus, and importantly the Web community for testing this version for us. We‚Äôll continue to provide necessary updates to A-Frame.

We‚Äôd also like to celebrate now 300+ contributors, 10,000+ GitHub stars, and 300+ email subscribers to the A-Frame project.

If you‚Äôd like to continue to support us, please subscribe to the A-Frame newsletter where we‚Äôll not only provide updates and showcase community projects, but requests for testing and user feedback support every now and then to keep us going in this grassroots project.

Read the release notes and changelog.

A-Frame 1.0.0 is out! ü•≥ With full WebXR support shipping now in Chrome 79 and Oculus Browser stable channels. Deliver VR experiences instantaneously to millions of users today! Happy immersive Christmas! üéÑ

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 16, 2019

We're still at it! Today marks the exact date of @aframevr's fourth birthday, and we're excited to release v1 with the help of the #WebVR community. https://t.co/rlvFSpjBvu https://t.co/DHgRoEgb9f

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) December 16, 2019

For those who are using AR.js with #aframe in WebAR apps, please import latest #aframe, v1.0.0 has been shipped üöÄ

This will avoid problems with new Chrome 79 that has WebXR Device API enabled by default.

Thanks to @aframevr team for the great work. It's outstanding.

— Nicol√≤ Carpignoli (@nicolocarp)

This will avoid problems with new Chrome 79 that has WebXR Device API enabled by default.

Thanks to @aframevr team for the great work. It's outstanding.

— Nicol√≤ Carpignoli (@nicolocarp) December 15, 2019

?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw‚Äù>December 15, 2019

Hey devs! üëã Remember to serve your content over HTTPS to enter VR mode in Chrome with A-Frame 1.0.0. WebXR is not available over HTTP.

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 16, 2019

üéâI'm SUPER excited for the 1.0.0 release of @aframevr now that #WebXR is shipping in Chrome 79üéâ
There's SO much potential of merging spatial computing with the open web to form the #widerweb & early seeds for what may become "The Metaverse."
Congrats to the @supermediumvr team! https://t.co/FuEgbBstFS

— Kent Bye VoicesOfVR (@kentbye) December 16, 2019

item.title: A-Frame Newsletter 1
item.description:
The return of the A-Frame roundups! Thank you for subscribing to the email newsletter if you have! If you have not already, subscribe through aframe.io/subscribe.

A-Frame v1 with WebXR and AR support will be releasing shortly as the industry-wide rollout of WebXR commences. Everything is ready to go after a bit more testing. After years of work, we‚Äôre excited to be ready for the wave on day 1.

And we‚Äôre excited to release Night Sky, a VR planetarium built with A-Frame to look and learn about the stars! You can set your location and see constellations above you in real time.

Without further ado, check out cool A-Frame projects from the recent months.

Built a huge 5ft Gameboy you can fully play in Web VR - https://t.co/RxkwFVwtPO - open source & made with @aframevr @dmarcos @Tojiro pic.twitter.com/nUsdLOqLTd

— Tal Kol (@koltal) December 6, 2019

Built Flappy Birds VR with @aframevr ! WebVR is awesome. Warning, game is intense - https://t.co/Z1b4fqoX9E pic.twitter.com/fCGvYcWEq2

— Tal Kol (@koltal) November 20, 2019

A demo of the different modes and opportunities to workout with Towermax Fitness Drill Track.
The length of running you see is 6 meters, in VR it's 12 meters with the room extender.
Full Video here:https://t.co/dHF3bsg4E2#vrfitness #OculusQuest #webxr #runningmotivation pic.twitter.com/UtukWV5zAe

— TowermaxFitness (@towermaxfitness) November 19, 2019

Thank you @spaceappslondon √¢¬ò¬Ñ√Ø¬∏¬èHad a blast playing with @aframevr again + NASA models to make this with @Rushlet_ and @PrinaShah2 The story from Apollo to Artemis in webVR: https://t.co/bh4U7bBrr6 √∞¬ü¬å¬ô √∞¬ü¬é¬ß pic.twitter.com/oN3Yly5GRi

— Sumi Senthi (@SumiSenthi) October 20, 2019

Slowly learning how to play a #WebVR marimba.
You can try it out here: https://t.co/xpS5mIwia2
Made with @aframevr and #threejs #VR #music #instrument pic.twitter.com/uRfsoS3QUY

— Oliver Fei (@OliverFei_VR) November 26, 2019

Done and submitted. Here's a clip of yesterdays stream playing the finished the @aframevr #webxr game build for the #js13k competition. It's intense... pic.twitter.com/xENSMiSgLA

— √â¬¨√Ñ¬±√â¬±√â¬±√°¬É¬ß √Ü¬ô√Ü¬°√Ü¬ô√Ü¬ô√â¬õ √∞¬ü¬å¬∑ (@Sorskoot) September 13, 2019

Amazing AR poster made by @tzs007 for @HBO using @aframevr Awesome work! √∞¬ü¬ë¬è pic.twitter.com/Jdm7XbG65P

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 1, 2019

Added haptics, keyboard support, a basic menu system, and a name to the #WebVR rhythm game prototype I made a while ago with @aframevr.

You can now play Cadenza!! here: https://t.co/wDzrUnvRtW

— Oliver Fei (@OliverFei_VR) August 11, 2019

We got new enter AR / VR icons!üéâThanks to @klausweidner @theDart76 @brendanciccone @andgokevin designs and everyone that provided feedback. Leave your thoughts in the commentsüëá pic.twitter.com/loDglNJjXA

— A-Frame (@aframevr) December 2, 2019

Here's a sneak peek at a feature in the upcoming "Barista Express" update!@MadeWithAFrame @aframevr #webvr #webxr #vr #barista #gamedev #aframe pic.twitter.com/5t6vaMhmuH

— Construct Arcade (@ConstructArcade) October 22, 2019

Yay! New office doggy √Ø¬ø¬Ω√Ø¬ø¬Ω@googlechrome is now shipping AR √∞¬ü¬ë¬ì experimental features as part of the WebXR implementation. You can play with them today using @aframevr thanks to @klausweidner Have fun! Instructions in the comments pic.twitter.com/PyFHUDbjrN

— Diego (@dmarcos) October 29, 2019

US Civil War resurrection with @aframevr using #ARjshttps://t.co/FDVTUdIywc pic.twitter.com/rj1Jrtz7VH

— Vinh T Nguyen (@VinhTTU) August 22, 2019

The terrain-walk is a separate component which does not use physics or navmesh navigation. The terrain geometry is a simple mesh. The topography is generated by displacements in the vertex shader.

— SirFizX (@SirFizX_ELHS) August 11, 2019

Articles

If you have followed our weekend inspiration about #webVR and the awesome @aframevr framework you should also check out this tutorial by @Srushtika on @pluralsight about "Build a #Multiplayer VR App that works In Realtime": https://t.co/VPl6YvhUXr#webdevelopment #VirtualReality pic.twitter.com/xkqyQThjha

— Wacky Studio (@WackyStudioDK) October 5, 2019

Events

It‚Äôs all-go at this afternoon‚Äôs Creative Digital session at #TheMitchell with coders working on sound FX in @Sonic_Pi , @aframevr particle scenes and mentor Jamie‚Äôs prototype @arduino Warp Core @GlasgowLib @glasgowlife pic.twitter.com/WErBDFx0P2

— CoderDojo Scotland (@CoderScot) August 17, 2019

Example of what our students are doing for our @aframevr seminars: https://t.co/QKj1XA3VdZ Run through the moving boxes, avoid falling down in the void. Features a bit of JavaScript, but mostly HTML pic.twitter.com/6lO7GKxmzQ

— Jesus M Gonzalez-Barahona (@jgbarah) October 17, 2019

Made a @glitch version of my #mozfest19 @aframevr workshop for @HackSussex today: https://t.co/fkMkG0EPap Zero setup required. Gotta love how easy glitch makes things!

— Edward Silverton (@edsilv) November 9, 2019

Tonight we shared our free plant biology education apps (feat #OculusQuest, @aframevr, and 360 video) with >100 üå± ‚ù§Ô∏èers at our #VRPlants pavilion here at #PlantBio19. Proud of our team's work over the past year. Miss us tonight? Stop by and try it all out until Wednesday! pic.twitter.com/9Od9miOe4x

— Colin Keenan (@technobotanist) August 4, 2019

Big thanks üôèüëè to @ironandsilk and @therlabnyc for providing me with the opportunity to teach #immersiveweb technology #webxr #ar #vr @aframevr #arjs @glitch at the wizard of oz themed UX masterclass this weekend, enchanted by the wicked witch üßô‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüå™üåà üë†ü¶Å pic.twitter.com/IWGO8I4eOG

— Roland Dubois (@rolanddubois) September 23, 2019

Talking about networked @aframevr #Aframe_nyc @HaydenLee37 pic.twitter.com/m2L5KSgiIt

— Roland Dubois (@rolanddubois) July 25, 2019

From Draft to Build: A-Robot Avatar https://t.co/W4looaq7TD #aframe_nyc @aframevr

— Roland Dubois (@rolanddubois) July 23, 2019

Enabling researchers to use virtual reality technology in their research @UoMLibrary @uomdigilab ‚ÄòVR for research‚Äô workshop yesterday - VR & special collections, new Oculus (which is incredible!) & training in creating VR content using @aframevr #virtualreality #VR pic.twitter.com/zLp6bkI4Rn

— Lorraine Beard (@lozbeard) July 30, 2019

We're halfway through our @aframevr pilot workshop. These lovely people are helping us create a better workshop whilst also learning about A-Frame pic.twitter.com/zSt3ccbsUX

— DigiLab (@uomdigilab) July 29, 2019

Had a great time presenting at the latest @aframevr Meetup @therlabnyc alongside @HaydenLee37. Thanks for the invitation @rolanddubois! https://t.co/wJAoEHEQId

— Composure (@ComposureInc) July 26, 2019

Had a great time learning about making multiplayer WebXR Experiences! Thanks @rolanddubois @HaydenLee37 @aframevr , also that's me on that video yay! https://t.co/eQUNFJUK7y

— Saul Pena (@Saul_Developer) July 26, 2019

Had a lot of fun learning how to implement networked social WebVR (and adorable robot avatars ü§ñü§ñ) with @rolanddubois @haydenlee37 @aframevr #aframe_nyc #aframenyc pic.twitter.com/ySh67CDcqP

— Pilar Aranda (@ImmersivePilar) July 26, 2019

Miscellaneous

Dunno how long it will be up for, but I was messing around with @aframevr and learning how to create components so spawning new entities is as easy as manipulating the DOM. #VR #3d #webgl #threejshttps://t.co/rXzg8AIQSB

— RedYeti.co (@RedYetiCo) November 12, 2019

Thanks to @aframevr , @glitch , and @CSTAMaine our small computer science education community is starting to grow!https://t.co/rad7TM2PLw

— CS1 Game Engine (@CS1_Game_Engine) November 9, 2019

WebVR 1.0, A-frame 0.9.2 Advanced Hello World code walk-through https://t.co/cWvOFNBEbW via @YouTube #aframevr #webvr #virtualreality @aframevr #webdevelopment #webdev #webdeveloper #webxr #OculusQuest pic.twitter.com/q5blc2TuYe

— Michael McAnally (@Michael_Blade) August 12, 2019

#VSCode has an add-on to preview GLTF models right in the editor!! ü§©

Also, @aframevr is simply too much fun to mess around with. Every discovery sparks new ideas for fun things to build!#WebVR #aframe #webdevelopment pic.twitter.com/7DuWWnYmq1

— Griffen Fargo (@GhFargo) October 13, 2019

I've said it before and I'll say it again; @aframevr is an amazing library. #webvr

Using it to build out a new personal homepage and really excited how its turning out. Hoping to have a preliminary version up either today or tomorrow.

— Griffen Fargo (@GhFargo) October 9, 2019

https://t.co/nxb56LxqYr a #coding tutorial #video on using @aframevr to build a simple #VR cinema #app #webdevelopment #learntocode #programming #webdev #html #aframe

— Michael McAnally (@Michael_Blade) July 23, 2019

@aframevr magic window mode is back on track on iOS 13 üí´ We now have a customizable dialog to request users access to the device orientation. Thanks for the patience and the hard work of @KevinEverywhere üôè Available now on master builds: https://t.co/DZRXcCKLjT pic.twitter.com/TmMe3kU9V1

— Diego (@dmarcos) November 19, 2019

Although I'm a React enthusiast, I've switched from React 360 to @aframevr . More convenient, better API and excellent performance.

They're meant a bit different use cases. But in general, IMO, you get much more done with A-Frame.

Says the guy who owns https://t.co/G7WcNYHS6r

— Samuli Hakoniemi (@zvona) December 2, 2019

Nate Landon graduated in June with a degree in economics...and now he's teaching the basics of VR using A-Frame! üòÆ

Saving this for after the U.S. holidays. Looking forward to showcasing the latest work in @aframevr. Subscribe to get the drop. https://t.co/gJRBemTgKR

— Kevin Ngo üß¢ (@andgokevin) November 27, 2019

Wow! In less the 24 hours the @aframevr community jumped right in to create amazing icon designs for the new AR mode. You rock ü§ò https://t.co/jeortlfEQT

— Diego (@dmarcos) November 25, 2019

Great opportunity to work in VR / AR with @aframevr and help improve science education in a top university. I myself lived in Geneva. Switzerland and the @EPFL are wonderful places to live and work. Highly recommend üëç https://t.co/8XTa9tNLDn

— Diego (@dmarcos) November 21, 2019

Good chart to understand the A-Frame Stack. @aframevr #WebXR
Source from: https://t.co/6CBLT9jUhg pic.twitter.com/OayRbINt9e

item.title: A Week of A-Frame 162 + 163
item.description:
We've released @aframevr v0Ô∏è‚É£.9Ô∏è‚É£.1Ô∏è‚É£! Follow up fixes and improvements to 0.9.0 such as WebXR compatibility and browser updates, new component events API, and improved animation performance. https://t.co/bFF0mUVZho

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) April 25, 2019

üîß We've released @aframevr v0.9.2 with fixes and improvements around link traversal and auto-entering VR where supported (e.g., @supermediumvr). Thanks to @sromline @towermaxfitness for reporting the issue and helping us track it down! https://t.co/MKVUkvyX1H

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 7, 2019

üî∑ What will be the equivalent of the Hugo Award for VR? Come catch a glimpse with Blue Cyber, a science fantasy VR series. You are charged to protect the galaxy, given the powers from a mysterious artifact. Experience episode 1, now playing on @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/RbpqA1VN8G

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 3, 2019

üëæ A multi-legged procedural creature swirls around you. Does it want to play? Built with @aframevr by @snayyss and @kif11. Visit Monster or Friend in @supermediumvr. pic.twitter.com/mC1m2jB4Xo

— Supermedium (@supermediumvr) May 8, 2019
